Type 2 diabetes is the most common type of diabetes and is characterized by insulin resistance. The insulin is ineffective in the body, resulting in rising blood sugar levels. To lower these blood sugar levels, the pancreas produces more insulin. Over time, this can exhaust the pancreas resulting in less insulin production and rising blood sugar levels.\nInsulin, a hormone produced by the pancreas, is essential for the processing of glucose from food in the body. Carbohydrates in food are broken down into glucose in the stomach and intestines. Glucose is then by cells in the intestines and released into the bloodstream to be transported throughout the body. Glucose is used for energy production in cells.\nHowever, glucose is unable to pass through the cell membrane of most cells. Insulin stimulates the uptake of glucose into cells. Being unable to produce or use insulin effectively leads to increased blood sugar levels (hyperglycaemia), which can cause serious health problems.

Type 2 diabetes is caused by several factors including genetic predisposition, increasing age and modifiable lifestyle factors such as:
 - Being overweight or obese
 - Unhealthy diet
 - Physical inactivity
 - Smoking
 - Certain medicines

Type 2 diabetes patients have an increased risk of developing serious diseases including:
 - Cardiovascular disease
 - Kidney damage
 - Nerve damage
 - Eye damage
 - Slow healing wounds
 - Alzheimer's disease

In nearly all high-income countries, diabetes is the primary cause of blindness, cardiovascular disease, lower limb amputation and kidney failure.

Type 2 diabetes can be managed through lifestyle modification including regular exercise, a healthy diet, maintaining a healthy body weight and smoking cessation.\nHowever, type 2 diabetes is a progressive disease, which means that the pancreas may not be able to produce enough insulin to keep the blood sugar level within the target range, regardless of the lifestyle modification. People with type 2 diabetes should then take oral medication to keep the blood sugar level within the target range. \nIf this is still not sufficient, insulin injections may be necessary. The injections and oral medication are intended to be used in combination with regular exercise and healthy eating, not as a substitute.

Stretching is a way to physically exercise in which we flex or extend specific muscles, it is usually done to make the muscles feel better and to loosen them up to prevent injuries. It is a sort of exercise which can have equally important benefits as walking or running. Diabetes patients are frequently observed with limited joint mobility and this can lead to lower their quality of life. Stretching can help people recover from injuries faster, prevent them, gain flexibility and range of motion, reduce the risk of falling, and improve sleep. To reduce the risk of falling is very important in diabetes patients because it can mean having to stop exercising for a while because of an injury, which is not good for them.[1] Stretching exercises do not have to be necessarily done alone at home and can be practiced in different ways. Three very effective ways to stretch are yoga, tai chi and Pilates, they combine strengthening and movement with stretching for optimum results. Another way to gain flexibility is by doing aquatic exercises in a pool, especially for people who are overweight, water removes the body weight while reducing the risk of injury.[2] A few studies have been done about the benefits of stretching for the diabetes type 2 patients, but it is proven that 20 minutes of stretching has a significant effect on the reduction of the immediate blood glucose levels, and that the effects remain for 1 hour after finishing the stretching exercises.[3]

Before beginning to stretch it is important to consult which exercises will be practiced with the doctor. It is recommended to stretch after the muscles have had the chance to warm up a little, for example after walking for 5 minutes. When we start stretching it is recommendable to complete at last one stretch per major muscle group (chest, back, arms, shoulders, legs and the calves), each stretch should last between 15 and 30 seconds and we should complete equal stretching in both sides of the body. It is important not to hold the breath while stretching and breathe deeply during the exercises to relax the muscles more. Stretching should lengthen the muscle to the point of mild comfort, not by stretching longer you gain more flexibility faster, stretching exercises shouldn’t hurt.
